summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana considered an application by the Divestiture Implementation Committee (DIC) and one of its members, Emmanuel Amuzu Agbodo, to be joined as co-defendants in the case of Joseph Sam v. The Attorney-General, a constitutional challenge to Section 15 of the Divestiture of State Interests (Implementation) Law, 1993 (P.N.D.C.L. 326). The applicants argued that as entities directly protected by the indemnity clause in Section 15, they were necessary parties. The Court, per Ampiah, J.S.C., dismissed the application, holding that their presence was not necessary for the effective adjudication of the constitutional issue, which concerned the validity of the law rather than specific acts by the applicants. Other justices concurred, with Atuguba, J.S.C. providing a detailed analysis of the joinder rules under Supreme Court Rule 45(4) of C.I. 16, advocating for a broad interpretation to ensure all affected parties are heard, but ultimately agreeing with the dismissal on the grounds that the applicants had not demonstrated a direct legal interest distinct from the stateâ€™s. The ruling emphasized judicial economy and the avoidance of multiplicity of actions.
citations: AMON v. RAPHAEL TUCK & SONS LTD. (1956) 1 All E R 273
VANDERVELL'S TRUSTS LTD. V. WHITE (1971) A.C. 912
rationaleHighlights: The constitutional issue concerns the validity of Section 15 of P.N.D.C.L. 326, not specific acts by the applicants.
The applicants are not necessary parties as their interests are aligned with the state, represented by the Attorney-General.
Rule 45(4) of C.I. 16 allows broad joinder, but discretion must be exercised judiciously.
Joinder should not be granted where it risks delay or confusion without clear necessity.
Natural justice requires affected parties to be heard, but speculative interest is insufficient.
The primary objective is to avoid multiplicity of proceedings on the same issue.
The plaintiff did not initiate the joinder; the applicants sought it themselves despite indemnity.
The Court emphasized effectual and complete adjudication without unnecessary expansion of parties.
